There are two types of big men the NBA covets as role players -- the monstrous man who can eat up space inside, and the shot-blocking 3-point specialist. Maker is the latter. He's a fluid athlete with the potential to be an excellent perimeter shooter while possessing a huge wingspan to help swat shots on a 7-foot frame.
[Lacking a typical basketball upbringing](http://insider.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/16262564/nba-draft-prospect-thon-maker-unconventional-path-pay-off), Maker will need to grasp the NBA game quickly. What he learns now will determine how much he can grow as a player. -- Thorpe

Drummond is the best rebounder in the league, and his ability to create second-chance points via put-backs is rare. He has his clear faults, and a lot of this ranking is projection considering he's 23, but what he brings still has a lot of value.

It didn't really matter who the host was for me. It was the same sanctimonious bloviating from multiple panelists every week. I'm just not a fan of these debate, commentary-type shows that so populate the sports networks these days. It wasn't much more than a dressed-up *First Take* as far as I'm concerned. A good host (RIP John Saunders) can only do so much. And it was all dudes for the most part, as Deitsch points out.
Either *Buffy* or *Battlestar Galactica*, being probably the best high-content shows on my theoretical to-see list at this point.

WRITING.TEXT:
Purely athletically, workout measurement-wise, size-explosion ratio? Calvin.
I will say though, and this probably sounds crazy, but I've always thought still-big WRs like Julio and Dez are better natural physical profiles for the WR position. Calvin's sheer size and leg/stride length made it tough on him at times -- running routes, evading players in the open field, avoiding hard hits.
Of course, relative to that size and crazy length he was more of a freak athlete than Julio or Dez, so he made up for any hardships, but to me it was almost like Calvin was too much of a freak.
Sure. Again though, I don't know why you're defaulting to the most extreme usage of the term. Of course there are some people abusing it.

Look, race is a factor intertwined everywhere; there are racially-prejudiced (racist) actions, thoughts, utterances happening all the time. I've been guilty of those things, you have, most people have. It's a giant issue today as it ever was (albeit less so).
The real problem is not the acknowledgment of those things by calling out peoples' actions or collective actions as racist, or others in general as racist as a result of their actions (you are what you do, right?). Exaggerated judgements are only natural in an Obama-years environment of an exponentially-increased bar of awareness (i.e. there's a lot of racist shit going on, and more people are aware of that). On the spectrum you're going to get stuff that's ignored and some that's exaggerated.
The real issue IMO is people shutting down at the word. They don't like the idea that they can, if only relatively unconsciously, succumb to a dynamic they know is so rightfully fraught and damaging. 99% of people know racism is bad. They just don't like the idea that they're guilty of racially prejudicial things. It doesn't have to be malicious to be hurtful.

"Everyone is a racist"
Where is that dynamic you're arguing against? Who's calling everyone racist? Who's calling huge portions of people racist? Who's calling people racist and not specific actions of theirs? There are levels to this shit, and you automatically jump to the most extreme theoretical example.
Stanley Johnson is not going through a sophomore slump.

Haven't learned to build a fucking wall yet

He can already effectively guard the majority of 2s through 4s...Stanley is an interesting athlete: he's not explosive in the traditional sense, at least vertically, but he's super-strong and has quick feet for his size. He can obviously get better, as any 20 year-old could in virtually every area (he predictably had trouble tracking ATL-Korver a few weeks ago, for instance), but he does appear to have good instincts, and the physical profile is a valuable one.
Stanley Johnson was in high school 19 months ago

Idk about *good* rookie season, but Stanley is definitely progressing, and has looked quite good over the past three weeks or so. The sustained flashes are certainly there, the progression is there (he has clearly improved over last season as well as the beginning of this season). Calling him a bust at this point -- a 20-year-old with 114 NBA games under his belt -- is simply asinine.
And that's just offensively btw; he can already defend 2-4 effectively at the NBA level. That alone has a lot of value. If his offense -- and his shot especially (he does have over a 60% true shooting in January, fwiw -- he could be a really useful player.

It definitely got better as it went, and thus started relatively slowly -- at least compared to what it became by the end of the season -- but calling the first half of the season 'routine sitcom stuff' doesn't ring true to me. I don't think it ever had enough of those elements to make pointing it out mean much. From the get-go it was different, unique; it's what kept me as engaged as I was. It was always extremely serialized (which may render 'routine sitcom' moot on the spot).

Here's Dan Fienberg [on the subject](http://uproxx.com/hitfix/tv-s-best-of-the-decade-no-31-veronica-mars/):
But in that first season, again using his literary background as a foundation, Thomas unspooled a complicated and involving 22-episode mystery around Lilly Kanes murder, while also working in regular Encyclopedia Blonde-style weekly puzzles. The conclusion of the Lilly Kane arc may not have been flawless, but it was as good as it gets when it comes to that sort of thing.
Then, in the next season, Thomas decided (was told) to tone down the serialization, to make the series more accessible to new viewers. The dumbing down of the show did nothing to improve ratings and many things to mute what was so unique about the show. The mysteries became duller, the relationships became more strainer and forced. The second season had the genius of Steve Guttenberg, which salvaged it at least somewhat, but the third season had almost nothing to recommend it, unless you happened to be a big fan of Chris Lowells Piz.
That's certainly fair. Trump and some of his supporters trivializing real issues *is* a sore spot for many people, though.
I definitely remember reading that the network told Rob Thomas to lessen the serialization in the second season. And I gotta disagree; S2 was nothing more than OK for me.
The issue is not accuracy. It's how much people whose behavior needs the most examining should be coddled. The word is being used correctly. People don't like being called on their shit.

pretty funny stuff
I hope that's not your biggest takeaway here

If you're thinking about it, watch the first season at least. It gets a little dicy after that (due in large part to network interference), but S1 is tremendous and a classic. To this day it's on a short list of my favorite TV seasons.

Sports franchises are billionaires' play toys more than anything. They're not these guys' primary businesses for the most part (they had to get the money to buy the team somehow). Many of the teams don't even turn much of a profit. Lately valuations have been increasing due to TV deals, but that hasn't always been the case. They are toys; they are tools to gain fame and notoriety (see: Mark Cuban), etc...

He's had a litany of stuff as a Lion. Last year he had a mild ankle during the season (and it's hard to get injured when you're in street clothes every week). He missed 2016 OTAs and started camp on PUP, possibly after an offseason surgery. Soon after returning he got injured again and had to miss multiple preseason games (ankle). Mid-season this year after seeing the field he got hurt again (ankle) and had to miss time. Then he played again late in the year and once again got injured (foot) and had to go on IR.
Robinson's biggest problem is health; he's always injured. I don't think the Lions can really count on much from him.

His athleticism really worries me projection-wise. He's a genuinely [terrible athlete](https://3sigmaathlete.com/rankings/dl/). Especially in an attack-oriented DL scheme. And for a guy who's calling card was the run game, he looked really bad in that area this season, even considering he was a rookie. I don't think it's a stretch to say he was worse vs. the run than the pass, and he was baddd vs. the pass. I'll believe it when I see it with him; I'm not optimistic.
